Posts.Content: I was lucky by the sounds of it with no bone pain with Docetaxel.  I didn't get any infections but had allergic reactions during chemo twice, got burns with 3 of them, went off food.  It was strong but it had a really good impact on my tumour abd shrunk it loads.  Will find out if FEC has fone as good a job next week. 3 down, 1 to go ! Fingers crossed.
Posts.Title: Side effefts

Posts.Content: Leolady56 Hope you're feeling a bit better now. X
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Just thought I'd try and give you all a bit of encouragement.  Chemo is really tough and I know sometimes you don't think you'll get through it but you will. I've had the best news today.  Had to go back for my results after 6 months of chemo, lumpectomy and SNB 3 weeks ago.  I am CANCER FREE!!  What a Christmas pressie.  Still got rads in New Year sometime. You can do this!! Xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Jax68  I found FEC easier going than Docetaxel, although my veins got a bit sore and hard. AnnJac Thankyou.  Hope you're doing ok?!  Xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi AnnJac That's good that you've got your surgery plan.  I think you can start to see the light at the end of the tunnel.  It's amazing what they can do surgery wise now. I know what you mean about the sweet tooth during chemo.  That's the only thing I enjoyed.  Trouble is I'm still enjoying the sweet stuff!! I've got stiffness in my fingers sometimes, the after effects of chemo!! I'm going back to work in January on a phased return.  Will work around radiotherapy.  I can't wait to get some kind of normality back! Lisa xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I got cording with FEC.  It calmed down but have got it again after having my lumpectomy and SNB. I've got stretching exercises that help. Was also advised by physio to massage vein gently and add warmth to area.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: AnnJac I can't say I blame you for that decision, you've had a really tough time on the chemo. I'm sure you'll soon start to feel a bit better, just knowing you haven't got to have anymore chemo. Glad you had a lovely time visiting today. Lisa x
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Brilliant news TheScriptFan!!  Always good to hear. Chemo did that to mine too, now anxiously awaiting results of lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: TheScriptFan yes should be having radiotherapy.  Obviously depends on results.  If they find anything would prob mean more surgery.  If not, then 15 sessions of rads as far as I know. xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Congratulations Sunnycat on your last chemo.  Glad you rang the bell loudly!!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi AnnJac Blimey no wonder you're confused. I had 8 lots of chemo slyogether.  I had an MRI scan between chemo 4/5 and after 7.  My tumour had gone completely.  I then had a PE on the day I was supposed to have last chemo and ended up in hospital for 4 days.  Yhey still gave me my ladt chemo 4 days after. It maybe because I've got TNBC so I didn't miss any but they did reduce my last one down slightly.  I had op 6 1/2 weeks after last chemo.  It got delayed because of PE - fingers crossed I get good results on 18th!! Can you have a chat to your BC nurse.  I find mine really good if I'm in a quandry.  She can also ask some questions and liaise between surgeon snd Oncologist. Good luck x
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thankyou TheScriptFan!! Woohoo!! xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I have got 6 lovely Indian cotton head scarves, patterned and plain if anyone would like them for free.  They're all in lovely condition and clean.   Pm if you're interested.  I'd rather somebody got some use out of them.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Kathyx The injections are called Filasgrim, they're to boost your white blood cells.  They cost £400 an injection I found out.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I've finished chemo but still like to see how everyone is doing and if I'm able to help with anything
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Horsing Around I had Taxotere or Docetaxel as it's also called first.  I then had FEC. The Docetaxel worked well shrinking my tumour from 2.7cm to 1.2 cm.  The FEC did the rest, getting rid of my tumour altogether.  I had lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy 10 days ago.  Got to get my results on 18th! Good luck  x
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thanks Jax68 - It is a good feeling!!  As I left they made me an appointment for June and Jan 2020!   At least when you have your chemo, you know there's no cancer after your surgery which is brill!! Have a super Christmas and New Year xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Mrs50 I had the Filasgrim injections to boost my white blood cells.  I always tended to have mine in the evening.  If you do feel a bit achey, at least you can try and sleep through it. I didn't really have many aches or pains.  My final 2 chemos I had a night each time whete I felt achey but that was it. I had Docetaxel first and had to have 7 injections each time.  I had FEC afterwards and had to have 5 injections after each chemo. I didn't miss any chemo sessions as my bloods were always ok so worked for me. Good luck x
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: I didn't have a rash from the Docetaxel but my hands were peeling all the time and really dry.  Got through alot of E45 cream!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: TheScriptFan Aww what wonderful news CONGRATULATIONS!! A brill ending to the year!! X
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi kiwi_h Many thanks! Seemed a long journey but worth it! Hope you manage to get a good night's sleep! Lisa xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Mriana Sorry you're having such a terrible time.  You'll find lots of support on here.  Take care, big hug. X
Posts.Title: living alone with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi sarah316 Sorry that you find yourself joining the bc club but you'll find lots of support on here and you can ask anything, no question is a silly question. It's a massive shock to be told you have cancer. I felt more in control once I knew the trearment plan. Each chemo I had I knew was a step closer to getting better.  The side effects aren't always pleasant but it is doable. You will have plenty of support and there is always someone to call if you're not sure about anything. I've finished my chemo and my hair is starting to grow back but I have to say there are some brill wigs out there.  I've had so many compliments on mine and people would never know.  I've had more compliments than I did with my own hair!! I don't know how old your kids are but mine were 16 & 18 at the time.  My youngest was 2 weeks off taking her 1st GCSE but I did tell them and they've been brill. The only advice I can give you is to not look too far ahead and deal with each treatment as it comes.  I've had days where I've felt down and wanted to scream but on the whole I've stayed pretty positive and am determined to beat it!! All the very best!
Posts.Title: How to cope

Posts.Content: Hi sarah316 Sorry that you find yourself joining the bc club but you'll find lots of support on here and you can ask anything, no question is a silly question. It's a massive shock to be told you have cancer. I felt more in control once I knew the trearment plan. Each chemo I had I knew was a step closer to getting better.  The side effects aren't always pleasant but it is doable. You will have plenty of support and there is always someone to call if you're not sure about anything. I've finished my chemo and my hair is starting to grow back but I have to say there are some brill wigs out there.  I've had so many compliments on mine and people would never know.  I've had more compliments than I did with my own hair!! The only advice I can give you is to not look too far ahead and deal with each treatment as it comes.  I've had days where I've felt down and wanted to scream but on the whole I've stayed pretty positive and am determined to beat it!! All the very best!
Posts.Title: How to cope

Posts.Content: Whitby I hope all went well yesterday.  I have to say personally, I found rads a doddle compared to chemo and it was over so quickly. Just keep moisturising.  I had my last one on 5th March. Good luck at the breast clinic. X
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Radiotherapy Chat***

Posts.Content: I finished chemo back in October but here if anyone wants t9 ask anyth8ng that I might be able to help with.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa When I had FEC, I could swallow but felt like I had a lump or a bubble in my throat for a few days and then it would go away again.   I didn't have it with Docetaxel.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: It never even crossed my mind about the boosters and Kennel Cough spray.  It wasn't mentioned either. I have 2 dogs, 1 has his in June (when I was on chemo) and the other December.  I stopped mine having the Kennel Cough a couple of years ago as they never go in kennels and it stressed my older dog out.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and my dog

Posts.Content: TheScriptFan Thankyou  xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Israel and Leolady56 Thanks ladies xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: chloecat45 Thankyou - feel a but nervous but will be glad when yhe first part is done. Take care x
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Thanks Leolady56 I'm ok, these things are sent to try us! Once I know what I'm doing either way I'll be ok but thankyou for your lovely words and hugs. X
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Stayed in so they could keep an eye on me because I'd had the embolism and had to wear leg compressors through the night. Hope it all goes ok for you tomorrow xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Brilliant SarahSS123!! Well done you!! You never think you're going to get there but you do.  Really pleased for you!! Hope you took a photo! Great results for you too so it's all worth it.  YAY!! I found I get a bit of stiffness in finger and knee joints when I first get up but not too bad once I'm up and moving around.I've been told this is from my chemo but should hopefully go eventually. I went for my radiotherapy scan and marking up today.  Start mine on 12th Feb and will have 15 sessions.  Then I can get on with stuff.  I have gone back to work on a phased return so feel like things are becoming a bit more "normal" whatever that is. Once your op is done, things will fly past. Thanks for letting me know how it went - so pleased :) xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: LondonLass, Leolady56 and TheScriptFan Thanks for your wise words ladies.  Radiotherapy never crossed my mind this morninig as an alternative, even though I was scheduled to have that after my op but will mention it when I speak to someone. Wasn't thinking straight! I'd rather them be safe, obviously don't want to end up croaking it from an embolism.  I think it's like you say, you have it all planned out and then it goes tits up (excuse the punn) and you just want to get back to some kind of normality. Will feel better once there's a plan of action again. Thanks again ladies Lisa xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: I've just got back from a meeting with an anaethetist (not sure of spelling) at the hospital as I am due to have my operation on the 26th of November. I had to see him as I suffered a pulminary embolism on 5th October, which should have been my last chemo - my 8th chemo. I had a hospital stay of 4 days and then had my final chemo 3 days after. Before all this happened, my op was due to be on the 7th Nov. He's basically said he feels it's too dangerous for me to have the op.  It's a big op and he says there's a high risk of another embolism.  I'm on blood thinning injections at the mo.  He said if I had another embolism during op or just after op, it's difficilt to treat and stop the bleeding. They may look at just checking my lymph nodes.  As far as I know, they are clear at mo but won't know until they're tested. He's going to speak to the surgeons, the hospital that treated me for the embolism (as he hasn't got all the written records from them, ie. How big it was, was it just the one etc) to see where we go from here. I know it's better to be safe than sorry but will now be worrying about the cancer spreading, especially as I haveTNBC as I don't know how long it will be delayed for .  The fear if the unknown I suppose. The chemo did work in the fact that it got rid of my tumour. Sorry for waffling!!
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat45 Thankyou.  Sounds like you've got alot going on too.  I hope your lesions turnnout yo be nothing too serious. I would have thought having a PE/blood clot would be quite a common occurence before an op.  You are more prone if you have cancer.  He also mentioned that sometines tgry fit a tube thst goes into one of the veins in the chest that acts as a filter and catches embolisms.  Let ne know how you get on - the very best of luck with everything. Xxx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Back home this afternoon after finally having my lumpectomy and lymph node biopsy - back in a week for wound check and results 3 weeks from now. Glad it's done, fingers crossed for good results!
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: I'm sure your results will match the MRI SarahSS123.  Chemo, although not nice,  can do such wonders.  It'll be nerve wracking for the results after your op but I bet they'll be good. Let me know how you're getting on xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: AnnJac - Thank you my lovely, hope you're feeling ok! Xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Just thought I'd update after having spoke to my BC Nurse. I am still going to have an op on the 26th but my op is now going to be in 2 stages so I'm not under general anaesthetic too long.  Anaesthetist didn't want me to have my original big op because the longer you're under, the higher the risk. So on 26th will be having lumpectomy and lymph nodes biopsy.  One surgeon will do one procedure, whilst another surgeon will do the other. Should take about an hour rather than 3 hours + I will then have radiotherapy and my reconstruction in a few months when the anaesthetist is happy. I'm so relieved, felt like I was in no man's land yesterday and worried about what was going to happen. Am glad I'll be able to go back to work for a bit too early nect year.
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Thanks AnnJac - hope you're doing ok?! xx

Posts.Content: Stayed in so they could keep an eye on me because I'd had the embolism and had to wear leg compressors through the night. Hope it all goes ok for you tomorrow xx

Great results for you too so it's all worth it.  YAY!! I found I get a bit of stiffness in finger and knee joints when I first get up but not too bad once I'm up and moving around.I've been told this is from my chemo but should hopefully go eventually. I went for my radiotherapy scan and marking up today.  Start mine on 12th Feb and will have 15 sessions.  Then I can get on with stuff.  I have gone back to work on a phased return so feel like things are becoming a bit more "normal" whatever that is. Once your op is done, things will fly past. Thanks for letting me know how it went - so pleased :) xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: I was originally going to have op on 7th Nov if my last chemo had happened on 5th Oct, so just over 4 weeks but plans had to change when I got embolism. I know 2 or 3 people who've worked through radiotherapy so will see how I get on.  I finished end of April so want some normality back plus money has dropped too now. Just hoping results are ok and I don't need more surgery. Xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: AP7 - Thank you
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Latest in my operation saga! Saw my surgeon on Friday morning.  She informed the anaethetist that they had got my op down to an hour and  reconstruction would be done later on.  He still wants the i's dotting and the t's crossed. They normally like 12 weeks of blood thinning injections to have dispersed clot, mine will be about 8 weeks. She has spoken to Haematology who seems quite happy for it to go forward. I'll be mobile after, it's not like I'm having a knee op and won't be able to move. I would also have the massaging leg wraps on during op and during the night. My surgeon was also trying to get hold of the Respiratory team and finding out who the anaethetist is supposed to be for ny op. So I now have an energency CT scan tomorrow and an Echogram on Weds to see if everything is ok to go ahead.  They're aiming for 26th but there could be a delay of 4 weeks worst case.  She is aware that I'm TNBC so knows how important it is to get op done. I'm really grateful thst they're looking after me but just want it done.  Don't want to be worrying about it spreading. Thanks for listening.
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: All scans back ok - my op is definately Monday (after all that) thank goodness!!
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: TheScriptFan Fantastic bet you're so relieved.  Really pleased for you!! Lumpectomy and 6 nodes removed for biopsy took about 1 hr 20 mins.  I've got an appointment a week today to check the wound and then 3 weeks today I go back for results (18th Dec). My breast care nurse said they recommend approx 3 weeks recovery.  If my results are ok will then have radiotherapy but hoping to go back to work on a phased return in Jan (work in a Nurture Group in a primary school) and fit radiotherapy around work. I want some normality back!! Hope you're celebrating tonight!! Xx

Posts.Content: I was originally going to have op on 7th Nov if my last chemo had happened on 5th Oct, so just over 4 weeks but plans had to change when I got embolism. I know 2 or 3 people who've worked through radiotherapy so will see how I get on.  I finished end of April so want some normality back plus money has dropped too now. Just hoping results are ok and I don't need more surgery. Xx

Lumpectomy and 6 nodes removed for biopsy took about 1 hr 20 mins.  I've got an appointment a week today to check the wound and then 3 weeks today I go back for results (18th Dec). My breast care nurse said they recommend approx 3 weeks recovery.  If my results are ok will then have radiotherapy but hoping to go back to work on a phased return in Jan (work in a Nurture Group in a primary school) and fit radiotherapy around work. Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Thanks TheScriptFan I'm relieved that it can go ahead, even if I have my reconstruction further down the line. Have you got to have surgery? I was nervous about my MRI at the end of chemo, even though I knew it had shrunk alot half way through.  I knew the Docetaxel had worked well but dudn't know if FEC would be the same but it was - no tumour in last MRI.  I've had a delay from my original op date of 7th Nov to 26th due to the embolism so hoping I get clear margins and nodes. I've still got to have radiotherapy.  I'm hoping to go back to work on a phased basis in January and will do my radiotherapy around work.  Alot of people do.  I've been off since the end of April - I need some "normality" back!! It's miney aswell.  I go to half pay this month from full pay.  Luckily I have enough to cover me for a couple of months. I'm sure you'll get good results and enjoy your Mum's 70th!! Xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Thanks SarahSS123.  A little bit sore but not too bad.  Just tired (very noisy on the ward last night) so looking forward to my own bed tonight. Hope you're doing ok! Xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly38 This is a great site for support.  It's ok to have bad days, we wouldn't be human if we didn't but try and stay positive. You've got this.  I found things easier and felt more in control when I started my treatment and I too, took one treatment at a time. The doctors/nurses do wonders nowadays.   Try and have a lively Christmss with your family. X
Posts.Title: The Fear is starting to hit now

Posts.Content: Sorry if you get several messages from me, the website is being updated I think and I'd double posted a reply and I deleted it but both disappeared. Anyway, I'm not sure if there's different types of Movicol (spelt right this time). Each box has 20 sachets in.  You just have to mix a sachet with cold water.  It says on mine I can take one or two sachets twice a day.  I've started with 1 twice a day and was able to go yesterday the first day of taking it. On my first course of FEC I had the runs for 2 days and my second, I had the worst constipation I've had throughout all my chemo. Had my third FEC Friday so third time lucky!! I find things improve once my steroids and anti-sickness tablets are done with. Good luck, hope you find a balance.
Posts.Title: Slight constipation

Posts.Content: My Oncolgist prescribed me Movakol to make the stools softer and easier to pass.
Posts.Title: Slight constipation

Posts.Content: Hi I hope you don't mind me contacting you but I was given some links to ladies that have had Licap op. I was originally down to have op on 7th Nov but has been postponed until 21st as I got a blood clot the same day I was supposed to have last chemo. I just wondered how it went and what your recovery time was like? Many thanks
Posts.Title: Licap Flap Tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi  Thanks for getting back to me, I don't know of many people that have had this op. I hope you're keeping well after all your treatment . Just a couple of questions: What was your recovery time? How long after op did you start your rads? Cheers jojo1969 X
Posts.Title: Licap Flap Tomorrow

Posts.Content: I was told to take temp every morning before drinking or eating anything.  I did this most of the time but often forgot.  I got to know what my temoerature tended to be around.  If it was higher or lower than normal,  I 'd do another reading an hour or so later.
Posts.Title: Temperature during Chemo

Posts.Content: Two weeks ago I did my first walk with my hubby.  It was supposed to be 6 miles but ended up being 9.  All flat walking with the odd incline. Yesterday we did another 9 mile walk with a couple of hills.  It's so lovely to get out.  We parked up at the livery yard where we keep our horses and set off.  Seeing lots of things I'd never see in a car, lots of hidden gems. We're hoping to do the Cleveland Way next year over a week, so this year is for me to get my fitness back. I got the great news just before Christmas that I was cancer free (I had TNBC).  Have still got to have rads shortly so will probably be smaller walks again for a while.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Managed to get out today with my husband and dogs - it was beautiful, like spring!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: They're brilliant Leolady56!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Good luck AnnJac! Hope all goes well xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: AnnJac Oh dear, you're having a right time of it!! Hope you've got some nice cake in that tin!! Xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I'm off walking again this weekend hopefully with the hubby.  Haven't done what I call a long walk (about 9 miles) for a month so it'll hurt.  I've invested in some new walking boots so must be serious!! Getting in a long walk before my rads start next Tues. Lovely looking at everyone's pictures.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Brilliant AnnJac Sounds like you've had a good walk this afternoon, even better when you go with someone else and you're too busy chatting to noticehow far you've walked. Xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Violetsniff Thankyou.  Yes you definitely never know who you're going to bump into.  I nipped to Tesco yesterday, kept seeing everyone I knew, it was like a Mothers meeting! AnnJac Thanks AnnJac.  Good luck with your op, at least it will be another hurdle out of the way and another step closer to the end! Will be thinking of you. I remember on Docetaxel, my legs were so weak I couldn''t walk far at all. Any bit of walking is good you'll be ready in your own time xx
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Great photos everyone.  I'm lucky Sunnyone, I have Derbyshire and the Peak District on my door step.  I'm off walking again Sunday buf not sure where yet. Happy walking everyone
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: boobyloo Brilliant news!!
Posts.Title: Clea

Posts.Content: You have to do what you think is best for you.  Can I ask if your bc is fed by hormones?  I'm TN so I feel I've had to go down the chemo route as it's tricky one!  Is it worth speaking to someone before you make that final decision (someone from McMillan that could maybe help you with your anxiety)? I'm not trying to sway your decision in any way but to maybe just weigh all the options up before your final decision. What ever you decide, I wish you the very best!
Posts.Title: A very hard decision

Posts.Content: Hi wigan59 Sorry you're not feeling well but it will get better.  I had 4 x Docetaxel and 4 x FEC.  I finished my chemo in October and had a lumpectomy end of November. I found my joints in my fingers got a bit stiff about 4/5 weeks after chemo but this is quite common.  It's much better now.  I also lost my taste buds and I think that was one of the things that got to me as I like my food.    They too are back, it took a few weeks but pretty much back to normal. You'll get there, it just takes a while.  You're body has been through so much.  You never think you're going to come out the other side but you will x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: I've got this op on 26th Nov and have to say I feel nervous. They'll be testing up to 4 lymph nodes to make sure it isn't in them. Hope your recovery goes well ladies.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy, LICAP and lymphnodes removed. Is this swellling norma...

Posts.Content: Rose2018 I didn't realise how serious it was until afterwards and there was I thinking I had trapped wind for 2 days!!
Posts.Title: PICC related thrombosis and Clexane Forte

Posts.Content: Gorilla1 Hi I'm on Clexabe Forte 120mg bit because if a clot from a PICC line but because I did get s PE in my lung.  I've got to be on daily injections for 6 months but am hopefully going onto oral form shortly. I do know someone who got s clot from Picc and she was on injections for 3 months.  I'm not sure what the injections were or the dose. When I was put on the 120mg I was told the dose was related to how much you weighed. Hope you're sorted now.
Posts.Title: PICC related thrombosis and Clexane Forte

Posts.Content: Hi KerryCake I had the BRAC1 & BRAC2 test done as I have TNBC.  They wanted to know if anyone in my family had breast cancer or ovarian cancer. It was a simple blood test, it took about 6 weeks for the results to come back.  Mine were negative.  If they'd been positive I was looking at having my ovaries removed and the option of a double masectomy. If you carry the gene you're more at risk of developing either bc or ovarian cancer but not always.
Posts.Title: Breast ovarian cancer link and genetic testing

Posts.Content: On the whole I'm pretty positive but today I've been on a right downer - feeling very sorry for myself so thought I'd come on here for a boost. I've got 1 chemo left from 8 on 5th October.  Think I'm just nervous as I had my 3rd MRI last Tues.  They'll be discussing me this Tues and then I'll find out if the FEC has worked aswell as the Docetaxel did.  Also the se's have got to me today. Anyway moan over.  I didn't want to really vent at home even though my family are very supportive. Thanks
Posts.Title: Cheering Up

Posts.Content: Thankyou Leolady, I've flicked the finger !! X
Posts.Title: Cheering Up

Posts.Content: Thank you Granny59 and TheScriptFan for your positive words.  It's nice that  people get where you're coming from and we can encourage each other. Yes, I had Docetaxel first and then FEC.  I'm on a trial so it was whichever one came out of the hat first. The only tips I would say for Docetaxel are to make sure you take your steroids to avoid allergic reactions (I didn't take mine properly second time)!! and to rest up afterwards.  I felt fine the day after but was the day after that I felt a bit off so I learnt just to take it easy. Good luck  on Tuesday x
Posts.Title: Cheering Up

Posts.Content: I'm glad you're getting lots of support Suebells.  I bet it all feels very surreal.  I'm glad you've still got your fighting head on Changing your diet is good - it can only be a positive thing. I'm sending you a massive hug Xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.

Posts.Content: Must have felt very strange. Hope amongst all your feelings, you managed to enjoy it. Xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.

Posts.Content: Oh Suebells I'm do sorry to read your reply.  I don't reall know what to say but I hope you're getting lots of support from family and friends. Was there a particular reason you refused chemo or was the prognosis still not good if you had it? I hope you defy your Oncologist's prediction. Xx
Posts.Title: Breast lump - frightened and miserable.

Posts.Content: Hi Julesy1 You haven't put your foot in it at all, I understood what you meant . Coming on here and talking to people really helps.  I made the mistake of googling TNBC - sounded doom & gloom but having spoken to lots of ladies that have beaten it, put a different prospective on it.  Google is outdated aswell. I was always one to be different!! You're also entitled to moan, it's a tough journey for all of us - we need to kick it's ass.
Posts.Title: Everything and the Big C

Posts.Content: I'm really pleased for you that you've had such good results.  I can understand being nervous about radiotherapy, you hear such mixed reports.  My friend sailed through it and went back to work.  Not sure about the Tamoxifen as I've got Triple Negative Breast Cancer so I won't be able to have it. All the best with your treatment.
Posts.Title: Everything and the Big C

Posts.Content: Hi AnnJac I had lumpectomy and removal of 8 lymph nodes so not quite as invasive as yours at the end of November and am still sore at times. I got some cording in my arm straight after op so couldn't stretch my arm straight out for a while.  My surgeon got me straight in with the physio. I've half way through my radiotherapy as of today but often have to put a heat pack on my sholder since op.  I was told they have to move your nerves etc to get to lymph nodes. You've had a big op so think it's a slow (frustrating) process x
Posts.Title: Arm movement, tightness and pain following mastectomy, axillary clearance...

Posts.Content: Hi Minty63 Sorry you find yourself here but this is a wonderful place to make friends and chat about things you're worried about. I found that I felt alot more settled once treatment had started.  Every treatment was a step to getting better. I took each treatment as it came and tried not to look too far ahead. I had TNBC so had everything they threw at me.  I had 4 x Docetaxel and 4 x FEC.  I didn't have a Picc line but should have really.  My veins did suffer alot. The chemo destroyed my tumour.  I still had a lumpectomy at the end of November, they removed the same amount of tissue that the tumour was and 8 lymph nodes for testing.  My results were all clear.  I'm just waiting to start radiotherapy.  3 weeks (15 sessions). I had my moments with chemo, I didn't have anything horrendous but sometimes it was the drip, drip effect of the chemo, ie. One day I might be a bit constipated, the next my taste buds were off but it's very doable.  Everyone is different.  If you're ever unsure about anything, just ask, there are plenty of lovely ladies, and some men, to answer any questions.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer diagnosis and terrified of chemotherapy and radiotherapy...

Posts.Content: Hi GILLY66 I had a full pathological response to chemo and had a lumpectomy, even though the tumour had gone.  They explained to me, even though there was no longer a tumour they still took away the same amount as the size of the tumour plus a bit more. As I'm not big busted they didn't know if this would leave quite a dent (my tumour started at 2.7cm) but wasn't as bad as I thought.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy Query

Posts.Content: Hi Lellyv What chemo are you having? I started with 4 x Docetaxel, followed by 4 x FEC. I did find Docetaxel a bit tougher than the FEC. I wasn't sick either.  If you're getting headaches from taking Oncadestron, have a word with your team, they'll probably change your medication. I couldn't drive for about 5 or 6 days after having Docetaxel as I felt very shaky and seemed ti have a bit of trouble with my eyes. I also lost my tastebuds which was annoying.  I think when you have your first chemo, it's the not knowing what to expect and what's normal.  I made a note of how I felt each day to see if there was a pattern.  After a couple of chemo sessions, I just seemed to get used to the side effects. I took each one as it came and kept thinking I was one step nearer to kicking it after every session. Didn't get purple boobs so can't help you on that one. Good luck with the rest of your treatment. Lisa x
Posts.Title: Morning ladies advice please.

Posts.Content: I used Aveeno cream and E45.  I kept my Aveeno cream in my bag that I took when I had my rads and my E45 for home.  Didn't get any burning. Aveeno is much lighter, still use it now sometimes.
Posts.Title: Can anyone advise which creams are best for moisturising after radiotherapy...

Posts.Content: @lellyv The lack of taste buds was horrible.  I like my food and found that a really hard side effect.  I can rwmember really fancying a Sunday dinner then couldn't eat it as it didn't taste right and thd texture wasn't good.   Yes Docetaxel is the T bit of FEC-T (Taxotere).  FEC is quite harsh on the veins.  If you're having chemo first before op, try and take it in turns with your arms to save your veins a bit. I've heard different people say they weren't supposed to eat different things but  I was never told not to eat snything.  I just ate whatever I fancied so that I was eating something.  I had quite a sweet tooth to be honest. It must be tough doing it on your own.  Just listen to your body and if you need to rest, make sure you do. I was given a 24 hour number to ring if I felt ill or was unsure about anything.. They were lovely.  I rang them a few times at the start of chemo because I didn't know if some of the things that were happening to me was normal or nit  They often put my mind at rest. It is scarey. I used Corsydll Daily Mouthwash too and was lucky, didn't get many mouth ulcers.  If you have any questions, just ask. Lisa x
Posts.Title: Morning ladies advice please.

Posts.Content: Thankyou SarahSS123 It seems such a journey at the beginning but you'll soon be putting it behind you.  The other way of looking at having chemo first, is you can see how your cancer reacts to chemo and if it's working and it is.  I know it's an anxious time but keep thinking that.  FEC is a good bc chemo too. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Long shot

Posts.Content: Hi Lellyv I didn't like the  thought of a Picc line at the time but wished I'd had one as it was a struggle towards the end - not always so much having the chemo but when I had to have bloods taken. They struggled when I ended up in hospital with my PE too trying to put a cannula in, ended up with it in a vein near my wrist bone! Let us know how you get on.   Lisa x
Posts.Title: Morning ladies advice please.

Posts.Content: Hi SarahSS123 Hope you're doing ok? It does sound like your chemo is doing it's job. I can't say my lump felt grissly and then was softer.  Our boobs are quite bumpy and grissly anyway so I shouldn't worry too much. I think it's easy to worry about things and wonder if things are ok. Speak to your Oncologist next time, I'm sure they'll  put your fears at rest x
Posts.Title: Long shot

Posts.Content: I'm not too bad thanks SarahSS123.  Just waiting to see if I can have my op on 26th.  I had a pulmonary embolism beginning of oct and it's delayed things!! FEC did wonders for my tumour aswell as Docetaxel.  Half way there, that's brilliant!! I'm sure missing the odd one won't have done too much harm, your body needs to be fit enough to cope. I think everything will be fine Tues, let us know! Xx
Posts.Title: Long shot

Posts.Content: Hi Haysie Sorry you find yourself with BC for a second time.  I was diagnosed last April with TNBC. I had 8 x chemo and 15 x radiotherapy (finished last one 5th March) and had a lumpectomy end of November. I just wanted you to know that the chemo is very doable and I had amazing results with it.  Got rid of my tumour and got clear margins and nothing in nodes. Please don't Google about TN - it's really outdated and doesn't show it in the best light.  Xx
Posts.Title: Cancer for a second time

Posts.Content: Haysie Fingers crossed that it isn't cancer but if it is, you can do it.  Like the other ladies said, they've caught it early as you've been monitored regularly. It must be gutting for you to be in this position but we're all here for you xx
Posts.Title: Cancer for a second time
